p.s: Emended description of Bifidobacterium thermacidophilum (Dong et al. 2000)
Bifidobacterium thermacidophilum (therm.a.ci.do′phi.lum. Gr. n. therme heat; N.L. n. acidum acid; N.L. adj. philum from Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. adj. thermacidophilum heat- and acid-loving).
Gram-positive, non-motile, non-spore-forming, irregular rods, 0·5×3–8 μm in size after 12–24 h growth in TPYG medium at 37 °C; strictly anaerobic, no gas is formed from glucose.
Optimum temperature for growth is 37–41 °C; temperature range for growth is 30–49·5 °C.
Optimum initial pH is 7·0–7·2, growth is quite good at pH 4·5 but is delayed at pH 4·0.
d-Fructose, galactose, d-glucose, maltose, melibiose, sucrose, d-raffinose, amidon, glycogen and d-turanose are fermented.
Mannitol, rhamnose and sorbose are not fermented.
Fermentation of l-arabinose, gluconate, inulin, lactose, d-mannose, methyl α-d-glucoside, ribose, salicin, trehalose and xylose is variable.
Litmus milk is not acidified or coagulated by most strains.
Fermentation products from glucose are acetic and lactic acids, at a molar ratio of 2·46–4·9 : 1.
